texts.content_text1: Before you get to the lecture, let's worm up and have a guess:
texts.content_text100: Children involved in court proceedings have the same procedural needs as adults.
texts.content_text300: Children require adapted procedures (child-friendly environments, trained professionals, simplified communication) because they are recognised as inherently vulnerable.
texts.content_text101: Children are recognised in international law as rights-holders.
texts.content_text102: The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC) recognises children as holders of their own rights, not merely objects of protection.
texts.content_text302: Child-friendly justice requires communication and procedures tailored to the child’s maturity and comprehension.
texts.content_text103: It is acceptable for child victims to meet the accused person during proceedings if it makes the process faster.
texts.content_text303: EU standards stress avoiding contact with defendants to prevent intimidation and secondary victimisation.
texts.content_text104: Children have the right to receive information in a way they can understand.
texts.content_text304: Children must be informed in an accessible, age-appropriate manner so they can effectively participate.
texts.content_text105: Specially trained professionals should conduct interviews with child victims.
texts.content_text305: Both international and EU frameworks promote trained interviewers and protective settings to ensure reliability of testimony and safeguard the child.
